People my age know very well that Senator Sanders does not have the qualifications nor the pragmatism that Clinton does. It isn't about that sort of thing, it's more about which candidate they trust more and which will put us in "the right direction." I am convinced, as many young voters are, that we cannot trust the former secretary to be a proper leader of the progressive movement since she seems to consistently have some connection to everything that progressives stand in opposition to. LGBTQ rights? As little as three years ago she didn't want gay marriage. Wall street? She gets absurd sums of money simply to give them speeches, and says she'll only release them to the public after the remaining candidates release theirs (including the Republicans, which she knows quite well will never happen).

We see Sanders as the United States' best chance to "catch up" with the rest of the world by offering things like universal healthcare and tuition-free college, or at the very least bringing that discussion to the table. To put it plainly we do not trust the secretary to even try to do these things, and frankly she's given us no reason to.

I feel like there's often an unspoken class divide underlying comments on health articles like this one. In this case, I'm guessing working class families are disproportionately represented among soda drinkers, and upper/upper middle class families are disproportionately represented among Times commenters. Thus, when the comments turn to blaming the consumers who make 'bad' health choices, or humble brags about what great choices the commenters make, I get uncomfortable. The best solutions to the obesity crisis will show an understanding of the realities of people's lives. I don't think shaming people, particularly when it's done by the more fortunate, is likely to get very far.

Really, Richard Luettgen, saying you think something is "rather" derivative when you haven't seen it sounds rather like hubris. I liked Gore Vidal's "Burr" a lot but i assure you, as he always does Vidal rather gives into whimsy and self-delight than does Miranda.  Rather.  Me, I am rather delighted you probably won't see it, not because you know so much about Hamilton -- I assure you that every night there are many who know more while also having the capacity to enjoy a work of genius and joy and classic tragedy -- but because it would be such a shame to waste a seat on someone who already knows [sic] he'll take Tarantino over the topic of the day that he has not even seen.

I haven't seen it -- ticket prices alone exclude literally 99% of the population -- though I've seen clips & interviews with Mr. Miranda. He alone is so handsome, articulate & charming that no doubt it has an effect on audiences. The show is tremendous theatre. But I believe much of the enthusiasm is for this "multi-culti" version of US History, that dovetails neatly with lefty liberal ideals -- wouldn't it have been super if our Founding Fathers were perfectly mixed group of all races? if the only bad guy was a WHITE king?

A kid who gets excited by this, THEN finds out that the real Alexander Hamilton was just another WASPy white guy, is going to have a major disappointment. And lose interest ASAP.

The analogy of Tarantino films is apt. If you saw those at a formative age, without much background (US schools do an especially abysmal job of teaching history) and THEN later found out that gee, apparently the Jews did NOT rise up to revengefully murder their Nazi oppressors....and gee, handsome escaped slaves did not return to the Plantation & summarily execute the slaveowners & their families in bloodbaths (with the help of some random German dude, couldn't even figure that one out myself). Indeed, had some Jewish European in 1943 -- or some black slave -- remotely done even one killing like this, they'd have been dead; tortured, gassed or lynched. Gee, not a fun story at all.

Richard, the only difference between you and William F. is that he used better words to disguise his extreme right wing agenda. Being wordy and ponderous is a poor way to communicate, as well as pretending to be tolerant by mentioning writers (Vidal) you despise.

Casting black and Latino actors as the founders seems rather derivative to me of Quentin Tarantino and his historical dreamscapes in which the deserving finally get their comeuppances at the hands of those whom they mistreated. But which is the more dramatic statement? A multi-ethnic American founders generation or “Inglourious Basterds”? Or “Django Unchained”? Frankly, for what-might-have-beens I’ll take Tarantino.

Alexander Hamilton was one of the most conflicted of our founders, a man of raging ambitions and not-very-subtle and just as raging insecurities rising from his low birth amid a group of landed grandees who were more central founders – and he was very young indeed during the Revolution (21 in 1776). His anti-slavery stance was about as energetic as he could away with in an early Republic that was so dominated by the South while he was still alive, under Washington and Jefferson; and that energy was far more nuanced and intellectual than the play is said to communicate. I haven’t seen it yet, and don’t know that I will – I probably know too much about Hamilton to really enjoy it.

The best treatment I’ve ever seen of Hamilton was Gore Vidal’s, a fictional but pretty well-researched one in the historical flashbacks we were offered in “Burr”. Not a lot about black and Latino co-founders came through in THAT character treatment. However, if this spectacle gets our kids and even adults excited about American history, I’m all for it, historical pedantry aside.

Assuming the USSF stays together and covers both the women and men then perhaps the financial reimbursement system should be "equal" for both teams. In other words the discussion about whether the men are equal to the women (hmm, I love watching both teams play but it is more fun to watch a team that plays well together and wins tournaments) is not the point.

Rather, the women generate x amount of revenue and the men generate y amount of revenue. Both the women and the men should receive z (the same) percent of pay from that revenue. I don't know how to structure different pay within the women's team (e.g. number of games player or minutes, etc).

As a father of two girls playing youth soccer, and as a human being, this pay inequity has got to stop. Go Ms Lloyd!

Revenue is irrelevant. I could post my own argument, but really Travis Waldron said it best:

"The revenue-based argument might make sense if international soccer existed in a market in which sportsmen and women have been afforded the same opportunities to succeed. But it doesn’t. So basing USWNT pay — or any international women’s team’s pay — solely on a market force like “revenue-generated income” ignores the ways in which the gatekeepers of international soccer have systematically suppressed the women’s game for years, keeping them from having the chance to generate similar revenues."

http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/uswnt-equal-pay-us-soccer_us_56fda31...

I think the fairest thing actually is that the American women's and men's federation split, so that there is separate accounting on both sides, and then the women are paid with respect to whatever money they bring in.  Apparently this has a good chance to be more than what the men earn, and we're done with it.  Unlike tennis when the men and women play roughly at the same time at major championships (so marketing dollars for instance cannot be distinguished), the men and women play at different times, so there  should be no major obstacle to getting up two separate books.

I saw the back and forth between Reich and Frank, and I thought Frank got the better of it.  Krugman is arguing in this column, quite correctly, that any Democrat in the White House would enforce the spirit and letter of reform and would appoint judges sympathetic to reform, while any Republican would undermine it.  He is also arguing that further reforms are necessary.  Both Bernie and Hillary agree further reforms are necessary.  Their differences are in the details.   Clinton has a very comprehensive plan, while Bernie's is pretty much Glass-Steagall, "break up the banks", and "release the transcripts.

Impervious to facts and reason, you say.  Bernie's prescience shows otherwise.  He accurately predicted the consequences of invading Iraq and of free "trade" agreements (all about the free flow of capital, actually) - notably with Panama, which has sprung into the news lately.

We need all kinds of reform, not just banking reform, and that has always been Sanders' point. The banks need their reform and non-financial institutions, like Met-Life, that have a big influence on the economy and the financial sector need theirs.

As for the contention that financial crises are rare, I disagree. Since the repeal of Glass-Steagall in the 1990's, we've been in a loop of worsening financial bubbles. Larry Summers has been warning about Secular Stagnation for the past two years and you have agreed with him since he began talking about it. Summers recently picked up on an Economist piece to renew the conversation on the topic of a new recession, too much Wall Street profit, and jobs. That threat is real and few are the US economists who have been writing about it. http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-29j

But back to non-financial institutions and the risks they pose... Sanders has never indicated that they aren't in need of their own reforms. He's been railing against the damage that money in politics has caused and the generalized corporate greed that has been rotting our society to its core.

While Prof. Krugman is not saying, now, that 2010 reforms weren't enough, former Congressman Barney Frank made an argument that is false about bank and risks in a hot debate against Robert Reich and made no sense. It's about consolidation and risk, as well as lack of regulation. http://wp.me/p2KJ3H-2ao

We need reforms in just about every sector of government to undo 30 years of rot.
